chunks.html_content:
If you recognise a union in your workplace there are certain rules you need to follow.

You must:

  • give the union information in advance to help with collective bargaining
  • inform and consult the union about major changes in the workplace
  • follow proper procedures if you’re taking union subscriptions straight from your employees’ pay (the ‘check off’)
  • let union reps and members have time off for union activities
  • not discriminate against a worker because they’re in the union
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
If you recognise a union in your workplace there are certain rules you need to follow.
You must:

  give the union information in advance to help with collective bargaining

  
inform and consult the union about major changes in the workplace
  follow proper procedures if you’re taking union subscriptions straight from your employees’ pay (the ‘check off’)
  let union reps and members have time off for union activities

  not discriminate against a worker because they’re in the union

chunks.html_content:
You’ll need to work with unions to discuss changes to your employees’ terms and conditions. This is called ‘collective bargaining’.

Collective bargaining covers the terms and conditions of workers in a defined ‘bargaining unit’. This can include all employees in a workplace or just certain groups of workers, for example technicians.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
You’ll need to work with unions to discuss changes to your employees’ terms and conditions. This is called ‘collective bargaining’.
Collective bargaining covers the terms and conditions of workers in a defined ‘bargaining unit’. This can include all employees in a workplace or just certain groups of workers, for example technicians.

chunks.html_content: It’s up to you and the union to agree which terms and conditions are covered but it’s usually things like pay, holiday, working hours etc.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
It’s up to you and the union to agree which terms and conditions are covered but it’s usually things like pay, holiday, working hours etc.

chunks.html_content:
Employers and unions need to work out how to run collective bargaining, for example:

  • who’ll represent the workers
  • who’s included in a bargaining unit
  • when and how often meetings will happen
  • what to do if more than one union is recognised
  • what will be discussed
  • what to do if the union and employer cannot come to an agreement
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
Running collective bargaining
Employers and unions need to work out how to run collective bargaining, for example:

  who’ll represent the workers
  who’s included in a bargaining unit
  when and how often meetings will happen
  what to do if more than one union is recognised
  what will be discussed
  what to do if the union and employer cannot come to an agreement

heading_context: Information to help with collective bargaining
chunks.html_content:
Employers must give certain information to the union to help it with the bargaining process, for example the company’s pay and benefits structure or information about its profits, assets and liabilities.

Read the Acas Code of Practice on disclosure of information to trade unions for collective bargaining purposes.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
Information to help with collective bargaining
Employers must give certain information to the union to help it with the bargaining process, for example the company’s pay and benefits structure or information about its profits, assets and liabilities.
Read the Acas Code of Practice on disclosure of information to trade unions for collective bargaining purposes.

chunks.html_content: If collective bargaining leads to an agreement, for example about a pay increase or change in working conditions, it’s called a ‘collective agreement’.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
Collective agreements
If collective bargaining leads to an agreement, for example about a pay increase or change in working conditions, it’s called a ‘collective agreement’.

chunks.html_content:
Employers must inform and consult with a recognised trade union about:

  • collective redundancies
  • transfers of business ownership
  • certain changes to pension schemes
  • health and safety
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
Employers must inform and consult with a recognised trade union about:

  collective redundancies
  transfers of business ownership
  certain changes to pension schemes
  health and safety

chunks.html_content: If you fail to consult the union about any of these, you’ll be breaking the law and could be fined - the amount depends on the situation.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
If you fail to consult the union about any of these, you’ll be breaking the law and could be fined - the amount depends on the situation.

chunks.html_content:
You can also make voluntary agreements with unions to regularly inform and consult them about other business and workplace issues.

Read detailed guidance for consulting employees and their representatives on the Acas website.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
You can also make voluntary agreements with unions to regularly inform and consult them about other business and workplace issues.
Read detailed guidance for consulting employees and their representatives on the Acas website.

chunks.html_content:
Some trade union members pay their union subscriptions directly out of their wages.

The employer then gives these payments to the union.

This is often called the ‘check-off’.

It’s up to you if you want to run the check-off. A union cannot force you to run the check-off unless you’ve agreed to it in your workers’ employment contracts.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
Authorising the check-off
Some trade union members pay their union subscriptions directly out of their wages.
The employer then gives these payments to the union.
This is often called the ‘check-off’.
It’s up to you if you want to run the check-off. A union cannot force you to run the check-off unless you’ve agreed to it in your workers’ employment contracts.

chunks.html_content: A worker must give you written permission to take their union subscriptions from their wages.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
Authorising the check-off
A worker must give you written permission to take their union subscriptions from their wages.

chunks.html_content:
This must be signed and dated. Their permission starts from this date and continues until they say otherwise.

If you take the check-off without proper permission you could be taken to an employment tribunal.

You can pre-print consent forms as long as the worker signs and dates the form themselves. Unions are also allowed to get the written consent from the worker then forward it to you.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
Authorising the check-off
This must be signed and dated. Their permission starts from this date and continues until they say otherwise.
If you take the check-off without proper permission you could be taken to an employment tribunal.
You can pre-print consent forms as long as the worker signs and dates the form themselves. Unions are also allowed to get the written consent from the worker then forward it to you.

chunks.html_content:
You must stop taking check-off payments if your employee asks you to.

They must give you written notice to stop the check-off and you must be given reasonable time to stop it.

You can stop running the check-off at any time. If it’s in your workers’ employment contracts, you may have to give them notice.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
Stopping the check-off
You must stop taking check-off payments if your employee asks you to.
They must give you written notice to stop the check-off and you must be given reasonable time to stop it.
You can stop running the check-off at any time. If it’s in your workers’ employment contracts, you may have to give them notice.

heading_context: The role of the union in the check-off
chunks.html_content:
The union does not have to help run the check-off. However, you can involve it if you want to. You could, for example, ask the union to help you get initial consent from its members.

You could also charge the union for the work involved in administering the check off.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
The role of the union in the check-off
The union does not have to help run the check-off. However, you can involve it if you want to. You could, for example, ask the union to help you get initial consent from its members.
You could also charge the union for the work involved in administering the check off.

heading_context: The role of the union in the check-off
chunks.html_content: Even if you involve the union in the check-off, it’s still your responsibility to make sure you make check-off deductions properly.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
The role of the union in the check-off
Even if you involve the union in the check-off, it’s still your responsibility to make sure you make check-off deductions properly.

chunks.html_content:
If you recognise a union, it will normally name one or more of your workers as its local workplace representatives (‘reps’).

Union reps have certain rights. They’re allowed reasonable time off work:

  • with pay for union duties and training at appropriate times
  • without pay to take part in union activities, for example the union’s annual conference (trade union members are entitled to this as well)
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
If you recognise a union, it will normally name one or more of your workers as its local workplace representatives (‘reps’).
Union reps have certain rights. They’re allowed reasonable time off work:

  with pay for union duties and training at appropriate times
  without pay to take part in union activities, for example the union’s annual conference (trade union members are entitled to this as well)

chunks.html_content: Reasonable time off does not have to be taken as annual leave.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
Reasonable time off does not have to be taken as annual leave.

chunks.html_content:
You cannot discriminate against anyone because they’re in the union or because of their union activity.

With rare exceptions, it’s also illegal to compile, use, sell or supply a ‘block list’ of union members that will be used to discriminate against them.
chunks.plain_content:
Working with trade unions: employers
Block lists
You cannot discriminate against anyone because they’re in the union or because of their union activity.
With rare exceptions, it’s also illegal to compile, use, sell or supply a ‘block list’ of union members that will be used to discriminate against them.
